responders outside of LAR, but would require additional resources from the LAR Fire Brigade.  The highest level of an emergency is Level 3, which is defined as an emergency of a size and scope that would require outside resources.  A Level 3 emergency is triggered when life and property are endangered or when the emergency could result or has resulted in offsite consequences. 

LAR maintains an industrial fire brigade that specializes in rescue, hazardous materials, and spill containment.  Each Emergency Response Team (ERT) is led by a captain and consists of six to nine members.  External sources provide assistance in the form of alerting the public, evacuation, transportation, and providing hazard mitigation equipment, supplies, and personnel to complement LAR capabilities. It should be emphasized that external assistance may only be requested during a Level 3 emergency.  

In addition to these sources, LAR has coordinated with the local hospitals, clinics, and doctors about the properties of the various types of hazardous materials processed and handled at the refinery.  All ERT members, ERT captains, and asset safety coordinators are required to attend quarterly onsite training.  Outside training is also provided annually to various ERT members, shift supervisors, and asset safety coordinators.  Coordination activities and discussions are held with local emergency response organizations and emergency training is provided annually to the emergency response team.  ICS role-play is provided to refinery personnel as part of the periodic emergency drill.


DESCRIPTION OF PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

LAR has several Process Safety Initiative teams that continually review and measure the PSM elements and develop best practice that will enhance PSM to meet regulatory requirements. Examples of process safety initiatives include:
- Corrosion control documents and pressurized equipment inspection studies
- Defect Elimination Teams
- Instrumentation protective functi

fatalities associated with this event, but several employees were taken to local hospitals as a result of exposure to H2S.  An investigation was conducted and multiple recommendations were issued to reduce the potential for recurrence of the incident.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Los Angeles Refinery has implemented an Emergency Response Program (ERP) to prepare for potential incidents, respond to them effectively, and recover from their impacts.  The ERP has included a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxic gases (ammonia and hydrogen sulfide), accidental release of flammable materials resulting in a fire and explosion, and accidental spill of hazardous materials on the ground within the refinery perimeter.  

LAR uses an Emergency Management Organization, known as Incident Command System (ICS), to respond and manage incidents.  The ICS has a hierarchical (chain of command) structure.  The  Incident Commander has the highest authority during an emergency.  The next level of responsibility resides on four section chiefs: Command Chief, Operations Chief, Planning Chief, and Logistics/Finance Chief.  All section chiefs receive directions from the Incident Commander during an emergency.  Each position in the organization has specific assignments and responsibilities, which are defined in the ERP.  The ICS is expanded or contracted to meet the needs or requirements of an emergency.  As the scope and complexity of an emergency expands so does the Incident Command System.

The refinery has a three-tier emergency activation system in place.  A Level 1 emergency is defined as an event, which can occur at a local work area (e.g., a unit), with minor consequences to health or property, which would not have an impact on the other units in the refinery.  A Level 1 emergency may be  handled by the personnel available on the unit.  A Level 2 emergency is a refinery emergency that would not require assistance from

Marathon Los Angeles Refinery.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human error.

In addition to these prevention program activities, the LAR facility has safety features on many units to help 1) contain/control a release, 2) quickly detect a release, and 3) reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection
- Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
- Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) detectors with alarms

Release Containment/Control
- Pressure relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
- Atmospheric pressure relief devices
- Valves to isolate the process (manual and automatic)
- Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, etc.)
- Diking to contain liquid releases
- Redundant equipment and instrumentation

Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Trained emergency response personnel
- Personal protective equipment (protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
- Blast resistant control rooms


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the past five years, there have been two incidents that met the RMP 5-Year accident release reporting criteria:

1.	On February 25, 2020, a fire occurred at the Carson Light End Depropanizer (LED).  The incident occurred due to leak from an overhead exchanger, leading to release of process material and a fire.  There were no injuries or offsite impact associated with this event.  An investigation was conducted and multiple recommendations, including installation of a chloride guard at the Reformer Units, were completed to reduce the potential for recurrence of the incident.  

2.	On May 4, 2023, a release of process material containing hydrogen sulfide occurred at the Wilmington Delayed Coking Unit.  There were no offsite or long term environmental impact nor

nd Accountability; and 4) Safety Program Performance. 

The findings from the PSCA are reviewed by a designated team representing various LAR departments (including contractors).  This team reviews all the survey results, and data, develops an action plan to address the survey concerns/results, and communicates the action plan to the Refinery Leadership Team. The recommendations are tracked to completion using the refinery database tracking system.  

A detailed description of analyzing LAR safety culture is provided in the Process Safety Culture Assessment (PSCA) Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-017)

Human Factors Program

The primary objective of LAR's Human Factors program is to eliminate the potential for human error, where possible.  The science of Human Factors is used to remove hazards, improve safety, and reduce the number of incidents in the work place.  

The human factors program established by Marathon Los Angeles Refinery have three main considerations:  a) ergonomics; b) cognitive human factors - matching design and procedures with cognitive capabilities and characteristics of the operator; and 3) safety culture.  

A two-phase approach is used to address these considerations.  The first approach is reactive and involves investigating incidents from a Human Factors perspective.  The second approach is proactive and involves evaluating the work place for human factor issues.  This approach is taken when conducting Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) studies, Management of Organization Change (MoOC), major change(s) identified from the MOC process, HCAs, and Operating and Maintenance Procedures reviews.  These two approaches work together to reduce the potential for human error to occur.  

A detailed description of the LAR human factors program is provided in Human Factors Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-015).


CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP and CalARP covered processes at the

R-PSM-016).

Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis

In addition to the PHA and SPA, LAR also conducts a Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis or HCA on all the existing processes as part of the 5-year revalidation cycle.  In addition, LAR performs an HCA for:  a) all PHA recommendations that identify a potential for a major incident; b) design and review of new processes, new process units, and new facilities, and their related process equipment; and c) on recommendations from incident investigations when a major incident occurs.  

The analysis is conducted by a team of experienced and qualified operating, technical, and maintenance personnel.   For each process safety hazard that is identified, the HCA review develops recommendations to eliminate and/or reduce the hazards.  Hazards are further reduced with passive, active and procedural safeguards.  

The HCA team findings, recommendations and associated action items are communicated and approved by area management, with priorities assigned. These recommendations and action items are tracked to completion using a database tracking system. The final resolution of findings are documented and retained in the same tracking system.  

A detailed description of LAR's HCA process is provided in Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis (HCA) Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-020).

Process Safety Culture Assessment

The primary goal of conducting a PSCA is to access and understand the site values toward safety and risk tolerance, based on survey responses by individuals in the site and the various work groups in the facility.  

The PSCA is organized in a manner that allows for breakdown of the results by work groups.  This allows for recognizing any subcultures that exist within the facility.  The assessment may include questions from four topic areas to thoroughly evaluate the site's safety culture.  These topic areas are: 1) Management Commitment and Leadership; 2) Individual Performance and Accountability; 3) Peer Perception a

A.  IPLs are independent of each other and independent of the initiating causes.  

The analyses are conducted using a team of experienced operating and maintenance personnel, as well as personnel with engineering expertise. The team evaluates the potential likelihood of the initiating events such as control failures, human errors and risk reduction achieved by the IPL. 

The SPA team findings, recommendations and associated action items are communicated and approved by area management, with priorities assigned. These recommendations and action items are tracked to completion using a database tracking system. The final resolution of findings are documented and retained in the same tracking system.  

This study is revalidated at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer in operation. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.
A detailed description of the LAR's SPA process is provided in Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-006).

Damage Mechanism Review (DMR)

The Refinery also has a comprehensive work process, which assimilates and analyzes corrosion data of refinery equipment and determines their corrosion rates.   This is known as the Damage Mechanism Review or DMR.  
DMR is performed for each process for which a damage mechanism exists and is revalidated every 5 years, reviewed as part of a PHA, Incident Investigation and a Major Change.  Team members performing the process unit DMR have expertise in engineering, operation of the processes, equipment/pipe inspection, and damage/failure mechanisms.  

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. LAR incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs, wherein procedures and work processes are currently in-place. 

A detailed description of the LAR Mechanical Integrity program is provided in Damage Mechanism Review (DMR) Standing Instructions (LA

ss.  In addition, the audit team interviews personnel spanning these covered processes. The audit team identifies gaps in the process, referred to as findings, which are reviewed communicated to the Refinery Leadership Team.  Corrective actions are developed by the site, tracked to completion and documented in a database system.  To comply with the regulatory requirements, an audit report is prepared to document the audit results. 

A detailed description of the LAR's Compliance Audit process is provided in PSM Compliance Audit Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-013).


California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program 4 and CalOSHA PSM Elements

Below are the CalARP Program 4 and California PSM Regulation elements:

Management of Organizational Change (MoOC)

LAR's MoOC program provides guidelines and tools for the review and evaluation of the impact of a Management of Organizational Change to ensure the change does not impact the safety of LAR employees or our surrounding community.  This work process includes an approval, implementation and documentation of permanent and temporary changes in organizational structure and personnel. 

MoOC team participants include personnel knowledgeable on the potential impact of the change and other impacted disciplines/departments.  The MoOC review includes an evaluation checklist and other supporting documents that are used to analyze the impact of the change (e.g. emergency procedures, etc.).

A detailed description of the LAR MoOC program is provided in Management of Organizational Change Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-002C). 

Safeguard Protection Analysis (SPA)

For each scenario that is identified in the PHA that has a potential of a major incident, the Los Angeles Refinery uses a semi-quantitative method known as the Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) to assess the integrity of the safeguards used to manage these hazards.  Safeguards that meet the criteria of Independent Protection Layers (IPLs) are used in the SP

improve yield or quality.  Equipment changes include, among others, change in materials of construction, equipment specifications, capacity, piping rearrangements, experimental equipment, computer program revisions, and changes in alarms and interlocks.  

Temporary changes are also subject to the management of change provisions in LAR-PSM 002 and the procedure also ensures that the equipment and operating procedures are returned to their original or designed conditions at the end of the temporary change.

Lastly, PSM related operating and maintenance procedures require a management of change when modifications to the procedures are completed.

Incident Investigation

LAR promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in personal injury, spills, fire/explosion, and release of a toxic or flammable material, major property damage, or environmental damage.  The goal of each incident investigation is to determine the root cause of an incident and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence. 

The investigation team documents and communicates their findings and recommendations to the Refinery Leadership Team for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are documented and tracked to completion. The investigation results are reviewed with all impacted personnel, including contractors. 

A detailed description of the LAR's Incident Investigation process is provided in Incident Investigation Standing Instructions (HSS-012) and Major Process Safety Incident Investigation Guideline (PSM-018).

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the various accident prevention programs and work processes are effectively implemented, the Marathon corporate Process Safety Group conducts audits of its operating facilities, including LAR. 

Compliance audits are conducted every three (3) years. The audit includes a review of documents and practices associated with each covered proce

breakdown maintenance is used rather than an ongoing mechanical integrity program.  Elements of the mechanical integrity program are as follows: (1) categorization of equipment and instrumentation, (2) inspection and testing program, (3) maintenance program, (4) documentation, and (5) quality assurance program.

Hot Work Permits

All non-routine work, and some routine work, that are conducted in process areas at the refinery are controlled using specific company instructions, described in the Standing Instruction, HSS-201 (also known as Safe Work Permit).  This specific company instruction includes Safe Work, Confined Space Entry, and Hot Work, which is described below. 
 
A hot work permit describes the steps that operating, maintenance and contractor personnel must follow to obtain the necessary clearance to perform different types of work involving hot surfaces, flame, or energized equipment.  The hazards identified for the work being performed are communicated to those personnel performing the work and to those personnel who may be affected by the work being performed, especially when the work being performed could affect the safety of the process.  The hot work permit procedures refer to and coordinate the following procedures and authorizations, as applicable: lockout/tagout, line breaking, and confined space entry.

Management of Change

LAR has implemented a Management of Change (MOC) procedure (Standing Instruction LAR-PSM-002) to manage changes to the refinery units.  Changes are defined as modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials, or processing conditions other than replacement in kind. 
 
The Management of Change procedure also covers changes in process technology and changes to equipment and instrumentation.  Changes in process technology can result from changes in production rates, raw materials, experimentation, equipment unavailability, new equipment, new product development, change in catalyst and changes in operating conditions to

ew - RSO) and PSM training that provides a standardized baseline of process safety training for all contractors that perform work.  Additionally, site-specific safety training is another requirement prior to contractors performing work. 

In addition, LAR evaluates contractor safety programs and performance as one of the key criteria for selection of a contractor to perform work in the refinery.  A description of the LAR's Contractors Safety Management Program is specified in HSS-011.

Pre-Startup Safety Review

At LAR, the Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) is conducted as part of the Management of Change (MOC) process for any new/modified facilities. PSSR confirms that prior to the introduction of hazardous materials to the process, the following are conducted: 1) field verification of the change and that it is in accordance with design specifications and applicable codes; 2) applicable procedures have been developed/revised to accurately capture the change; and 3) training and communication of the change has been provided to all impacted personnel.  

The PSSR should also be conducted as part of pre-commissioning (or start-up readiness) for activities following a turnaround, and for unplanned or partial shutdown. 

A detailed description of the LAR PSSR process is provided in Management of Change/Pre-Startup Safety Review Standing Instructions (LAR-PSM-002).

Mechanical Integrity

A Mechanical Integrity Program is in place for the continued integrity of process equipment at LAR.  Equipment used to process, transfer or store hazardous chemicals have been designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.  This program covers: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief systems and safety devices, emergency shutdown systems, electronic controls, and rotating equipment (e.g., pumps and compressors.)  LAR also reviews the maintenance programs and shutdown schedules to determine if there are areas where

es specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the operator's job tasks. Job specific training includes on-the-job training, a written manual, written test, observations, and written sign-off. 

LAR also has ongoing refresher and supplemental training for all personnel. Testing is conducted for all job specific training and craft qualification for each level of progression. Once an operator is qualified in a position, they are required to recertify for the job every three years through comprehensive testing. Testing is also conducted on all OSHA-required safety and health training.  Employee training and certification records are documented, both in hard copy and computerized training records.

A detailed description of LAR's training program for Operations is described in Process Specialist Progression Training Policy -O-1007 (Carson) and Operations Training Policy O-043 (Wilmington) and Process Safety Requalification for Maintenance Employees Policy for Maintenance.

Contractors

LAR uses contractors to supplement its work force to perform tasks requiring skills that are needed on a routine or non-routine basis. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in-place to ensure that contractors 1) perform their work in a safe manner, 2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, 3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, 4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, 5) understand and follow site safety rules, and 6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. 

The above goals are accomplished by providing contractors with a process overview, information about refinery safety and health hazards, emergency response plan requirements, and safe work practices. Additionally, all contractors that work on or near process units at LAR must have completed a compulsory training program a (Refinery Safety Overvi

the consequences from potential releases. 

The PHA team findings, recommendations and associated action items are communicated and approved by area management, with priorities assigned. These recommendations and action items are tracked to completion using a database tracking system. The final resolution of findings are documented and retained in the same tracking system.  A report is prepared on the PHA study and associated recommendations/findings. A detailed description of the LAR's PHA process is provided in Process Hazard Analysis Standing Instruction (LAR-PSM-003).

Operating Procedures

LAR maintains written procedures that address various modes of operation, such as 1) unit startup (following a turnaround or planned/unplanned shutdown, 2) normal operations, 3) temporary operations, 4) unit emergency shutdown, 5) normal shutdown, and 6) initial startup of a new process. The operating procedures are currently available to anyone working in or near a process area at the appropriate process unit control rooms. Critical procedures such as unit emergency procedures are reviewed annually during annual training sessions.  The operating procedures are also maintained in the Procedure Accelerator tool.  

A detailed description of the process used to update and create operating procedures is provided in Operating Procedures Requirements and Guidance Standing Instruction (O-200) and Maintenance Procedures Standing Instruction (MNT-001).

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations and maintenance, LAR has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating or maintaining a process, which includes front line supervision.  Initial training for operating and maintenance personnel who are new to a process includes health and safety training, Basic Operator Training (BOT), process overview and process fundamentals. Job specific training is then given to operators assigned to an operating unit. This training includ

(SDS). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, the refinery has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) contained in Operating Manuals.

The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g. automated shutdown systems).  The refinery also maintains documentation that provides information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety systems in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis

The Los Angeles Refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

The refinery uses the HazOp (Hazard Operability) analysis methodology.  The HazOp analysis is conducted with a team of experienced operating and maintenance personnel, as well as personnel with engineering expertise. The hazards of the process, identification of previous incidents involving accidental release or potential for such, engineering and administrative controls and failure, and human factors is addressed by the team performing the hazard analysis.  The PHA team also evaluates the likelihood of the potential hazards and the severity of

Marathon Los Angeles Refinery (LAR).  Because processes at the refinery that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management systems in place to implement the accident prevention program.  In addition, the prevention program includes California specific elements as part of the CalARP Program 4 and CalOSHA PSM for refineries regulations. 

Employee Participation

LAR provides for and encourages its employees and employee representatives to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation include participating as a team member of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Safeguard Protection Analysis (SPA) or LOPA, Hierarchy of Hazard Controls Analysis (HCA), Damage Mechanism Reviews (DMR) or Incident Investigation. 
Other LAR Employee Participation programs include the Stop Work Authority program associated with hazard reporting and response and the authority of Operations personnel to stabilize, slowdown or shutdown an operating unit based on an identified potential hazard.  

A detailed description of the LAR employee participation process is provided in Employee Participation Standing Instruction (LAR-PSM-001), Stop Work Authority (HSS-202), and Authority to Stabilize, Slowdown or Shutdown and Re-start Operating Units (O-082).

Process Safety Information

LAR maintains extensive documentation that is used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. This documentation addresses chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  
Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response information is provided in safety data sheets

ns hydrocracking, hydrotreating, fluid catalytic cracking, delayed coking, and alkylation processes.  
The two operating areas of the Marathon Los Angeles Refinery are described below:

1. Wilmington Operations

The Wilmington Operations is located in the City of Wilmington, California and is located in an area that is zoned for heavy industrial use.  The 299-acre area is divided by Pacific Coast Highway with most of the facility located to the north of the highway.  Sepulveda Boulevard and the Kinder Morgan Energy Company bound the northern portion of the refinery with Alameda Street and the Southern Pacific railroad tracks to the west and the Dominguez Channel to the east.  The area south of Pacific Coast Highway is a triangle-shaped parcel that approaches Anaheim Boulevard to the south and is bounded by Dominguez Channel to the east, and by the Marathon Marketing Sales Terminal to the west.

2. Carson Operations

The Carson Operations is located in the City of Carson, California and is located in an area that is zoned for heavy industrial use.  The site occupies a 650 acres area bounded by Wilmington Avenue on the West, Sepulveda Boulevard on the South, Alameda Street on the East, and East 223rd Street on the North.  The facility also includes the Watson Cogeneration Unit.  The Cogeneration Unit burns natural gas to produce electricity, which is sold to the SC Edison grid.  Waste heat from the process is then used to supply steam to the refinery for process use.

Based on the threshold quantities listed for regulated toxic substances in the RMP Rule, LAR handles one toxic substance, which ammonia.  The primary use of ammonia is in the air pollution control system for the reduction of emissions of nitrogen oxides. Additionally, several regulated flammable substances, such as hydrogen, propane, propylene, butane, pentane, etc. are present.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the

Marathon LOS ANGELES REFINERY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This summary provides an overview of the Marathon Los Angeles Refinery's Program to comply with the U.S. EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) and the California Accidental Release Prevention Plan (Cal ARP).


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES


The Marathon Los Angeles Refinery is committed to protecting the health and safety of its employees, contractors, customers, and the general public; conducting business in a manner that wins public confidence and meets the environmental and economic needs of the communities we serve.  This commitment is critical to our long-term success.

This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of our facilities, as well as in the training of our employees.  Our policy is to implement the necessary controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  If a release does occur, we have trained personnel who will respond to control and contain the release, thereby reducing potential impact on our surrounding community.  
 


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Marathon Los Angeles Refinery is comprised of two separate operating areas (Wilmington and Carson) that were connected through pipeline as part of the Los Angeles Refinery Integration and Compliance (LARIC) project.  Because the two operating areas are physically interconnected, share a common owner, and are located on contiguous property, the Marathon Los Angeles Refinery is a single stationary source and the Risk Management Plan was consolidated to reflect that fact. The refinery processes approximately 365,000 barrels per day of crude oil to produce a variety of petroleum products, including gasoline, jet fuel, diesel fuel, and petroleum coke, as well as products such as propylene, natural gas liquids, and other petrochemicals.  The refinery contai
